trigger: Expression of the <extra_id_0> nucleoside diphosphate kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in human skin cancers : an immunohistochemical study .

Expression of <extra_id_0> nucleoside diphosphate(NDP) kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which is homologous to the <extra_id_0> nm23 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene product in a variety of species , has been found to be inversely associated with metastatic potential .
However , the relationship remains controversial according to the tumor cell types and experimental system , with conflicting results from different research groups .

In order to determine whether <extra_id_0> NDP kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression serves as a marker for metastatic potential in human skin cancer , we assessed the levels of <extra_id_0> NDP kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in 9 keratoacanthomas ( KAs ) , 26 squamous cell carcinomas ( SCCs ) , and 25 basal cell carcinomas ( BCCs ) using immunohistochemistry .
The expression of <extra_id_0> NDP kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was intense in KA and SCC compared with BCC .
However , the difference of <extra_id_0> NDP kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression between KA and SCC was not statistically significant .
And there was no statistically significant difference in <extra_id_0> NDP kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression between SCC with metastasis and SCC without metastasis .
Our results contradict the hypothesis concerning the possible role of <extra_id_0> nm23 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene as a metastatic suppressor gene in human skin cancer .
The mechanism of overexpression in various tumor cell types and its biological significance in cutaneous carcinogenesis remain to be determined .
